metadata.title: Supplemental Information The Intergenic Recombinant HLA-B*46:01 Has a Distinctive Peptidome that Includes KIR2DL3 Ligands

body_text.text: (C) Analysis of the conserved residues at positions 2 and 9 and 3 and 9 in peptides bound by HLA-C*01:02. Shown is the identity and frequency of amino acids found at position 9 when alanine is present at position 2 (upper panel) or when proline is at position 3 (lower panel). 10 9 14 10 9 11 10 10 9 9 9 9 9 9 10 9 10 16 9 17 11 10 13 18 14 9 9 9 9 9 9 9 10 9 9 10 12 10 9 9 14 11 10 20 9 8 16 9 9 9 9 15 10 9 10 9 17 9 11 9 14 11 12 9 9 10 9 9 9 10 18 10 18 25 21 10 9 10 17 9 9 9 9 9 4.0 7. were made with web-based NetMHC 4.0 server (re-trained on the data included in this study) (Nielsen et al., 2003) .

(B) Shown is a representative gating strategy for defining CD107a expression in live KIR2DL3+/KIR3DL1-NK cells. Natural killer cells were isolated from five healthy KIR A haplotype and HLA-C1 homozygous donors by magnetic separation. Cells were analyzed on an LSR II cytometer (BD Biosciences) at the Stanford Flow Cytometry Core Facility.

Isolation and analysis of peptide ligands was performed as previously described Trolle et al., 2016; Yaciuk et al., 2014) . Bound peptides were dissociated from class I heavy and light chains by denaturation in 10% acetic acid for 15min at 75°C. Peptides were separated from the denatured proteins by passage through a stirred cell ultrafiltration device (3-kDa-cutoff membrane [Millipore] ). The filtrate containing peptides was lyophilized, re-suspended in 10% acetic acid and separated into ~40 fractions by reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) as described . Each fraction was dried and re-suspended in 10% acetic acid for liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS). Approximately 25% of each HPLC fraction was injected into a nano-scale reverse phase liquid chromatography Eksigent nano-LC-4000 (Sciex)

body_text.text: For the large-scale de novo identification of peptide ligands >10mg of purified sHLA were used.
body_text.section: Large scale de novo peptide sequencing by nano-scale LC-MS

body_text.text: Spectra were acquired in data-dependent acquisition (DDA) mode. The DDA spectra were collected for each of the off-line HPLC fractions for each HLA allotype separately. For each HLA allotype, the off-line fractions were combined in silico and interpreted using PEAKS 7.0 (Bioinformatic Solutions). Spectra were searched against the Uniprot Homo sapiens database.
body_text.section: Large scale de novo peptide sequencing by nano-scale LC-MS

body_text.text: All sequence assignments were made following a 1% false-discovery rate and precursor ions were within 50 ppm of the theoretical mass. A maximum of two variable modifications per peptide were allowed and these included: N-terminal acetylation, deamidation (Asn, Gln), oxidation (Met, Trp, His), pyro-glu from Gln, cysteinylation (Cys), sodium adduct (C-term, Asp, Glu). Peptides originating from HLA heavy and light chains were removed from the ligand list as they are known acid hydrolysis products. E.coli (EMD Millipore) and plated onto selective agar (50µg/ml kanamycin). For each construct, a 1L 2XYT culture (1.6% peptone, 1% yeast extract, 0.5% NaCl) with 50µg/ml kanamycin was inoculated with a single colony, expanded to an optical density at 600nm of 0.7 and protein production induced with addition of isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside (Life Technologies) to a final concentration of 0.5mM. The culture was incubated, shaking at 37°C for 6h following which cells were harvested by centrifugation. NK cell cytotoxicity assay using T2 cell lines

A representative gating strategy is each HLA molecule was calculated as the summed Kullback-Leibler distance (KLD) over the positions in the binding motif. A random subset of N 9mer peptides was sampled from the ligand data set of each HLA and amino acids frequencies (paa) estimated using sequences weighting and pseudo counts correction for low number of observations as previously described

FIGREF2.text: related to Figures 1 and 2: Table showing the sequences of shared peptides bound by HLA-B*15:01, C*01:02 and B*46:01 (A) Schematic showing seven subpopulations of peptides. These comprise three subpopulations that bind to only one of the three allotypes, three subpopulations that bind to two allotypes (A, B and C) and one subpopulation that binds to all three allotypes (D). Each circle represents all the peptides bound by each allotype (HLA-B*15:01 -red, HLA-C*01:02 -blue and HLA-B*46:01 -orange). The numbers listed in each circle represent the number of peptides that are unique to the listed allotype. (B) Table showing the identity of the shared peptides bound by the three subpopulations that bind to two allotypes (A, B and C) and the one subpopulation that binds to all three allotypes (D) Peptides are grouped according to their length. (E) Shown is a space filling model of HLA class I seen from above the top face and looking at the bound peptide. For each of the six peptide binding pockets (A, B, C, D, E and F) there is an alignment of the residues in HLA-B*46:01, HLA-B*15:01 and HLA-C*01:02 that are key positions within the pocket. HLA-B*46:01 is set as the reference sequence. The colored shading and dotted lead lines indicate the region of the HLA class I molecule that corresponds to each alignment.

FIGREF3.text: -B*46:01 HLA-C*01:02 leucine (L) glutamine (Q) tyrosine (Y) leucine (L) leucine (L) alanine (A) tyrosine (Y) leucine (L) proline (P) leucine (L) Analysis of the conserved residues of peptides bound by HLA-B*15:01, HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-C*01:02 Analysis of the conserved residues at the N-and C-terminal anchors for HLA-B*15:01, HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-C*01:02. Shown to the right are Kullback-Leibler sequence logos representing the peptide subsets shown to the left. The cumulative height of the column of amino acids represents the level of conservation at a given position and the specific residue height denotes its relative frequency. The colors of each amino acid correspond to their biochemical characteristics: acidic (red), basic (blue), hydrophobic (black) and neutral (green). Sequence logos were generated using the WebLogo server (weblogo.berkeley.edu) (Crooks et al., 2004). (A) Analysis of the conserved residues at positions 2 and 9 in peptides bound by HLA-B*15:01. Shown is the identity and frequency of amino acids found at position 2 of the peptide when tyrosine (upper panel) or leucine (lower panel) is present at position 9. (B) Analysis of the conserved residues at positions 2 and 9 in peptides bound by HLA-B*46:01. Shown is the identity and frequency of amino acids found at position 2 of the peptide when tyrosine (upper panel) or leucine (lower panel) is present at position 9.

FIGREF4.text: Table showing the sequences of KIR2DL3-permissive andnon KIR2DL3-permissive peptides bound by HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-Peptides bound by HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-C*01:02 that do not bind KIR2DL3 (non KIR2DL3-permissive). Peptides are grouped according to their length. Peptides used in cytotoxicity assays are shown in red. (C) Bar graph showing the sequences of six peptides bound by HLA-C*01:02 (blue bars, left panel) and 38 peptides bound by HLA-B*46:01 (orange bars, right panel) that are ligands for KIR2DL3. Shown for each peptide is the total intensity of that peptide in the peptidome as measured by mass spectrometry (grey bars, right y-axis) and the percentage of the peptide bound by KIR2DL3 (orange and blue bars, left y-axis). Peptides are listed from left to right in descending order of their relative binding to KIR2DL3. Octamer peptides are listed in red, nonamer peptides in regular type and decamer peptides in bold type.

FIGREF5.text: The minimum number of peptides that can account for half of the total mass of peptides bound by HLA-B*15:01, C*01:02 and B*46:01 For HLA-B*15:01 (left), HLA-C*01:02 (center) and HLA-B*46:01 (right) the sequences of the peptides and their length (L) are listed in order of decreasing abundance. With the addition of each peptide the cumulative sum (Sum) as a percentage is also given.

FIGREF7.text: related to Figures 3 and 5: Nonamer peptides derived from antigenic M. leprae proteins that are predicted to bind HLA-B*46:01 (A) Listed are the nonamer peptides derived from 22 antigenic M. leprae derived proteins that are predicted to bind HLA-B*46:01. Peptides are grouped according to their source protein which is listed above, along with the number of peptides that derive from it. Binding predictions

FIGREF8.text: Briefly, 721.221 cells, which lack endogenous HLA class I expression, were cultured in RPMI supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum. A construct encoding soluble forms of HLA-B*15:01, HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-C*01:02 (sHLA) were independently cloned into the pcDNA3.1 expression vector (Invitrogen) and then electroporated into HLA class I deficient 721.221 cells. The sHLA-peptide complexes were affinity purified from the cell-supernatant on an anti-W6/32 sepharose column. sHLA complexes were eluted from the column in a 0.1M glycine solution , pH 11 (Sigma) and immediately neutralized in a 1M TRIS solution and buffer exchanged into PBS containing 0.02% sodium azide. Purified protein was quantified by bicinchoninic acid assay (BCA) (Thermo-Fisher Scientific).

TABREF2.text: Table showing the predominant (bold type) and alternative (regular type) anchor residues present in HLA-B*15:01, HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-C*01:02.

TABREF6.text: Small scale de novo peptide sequencing to estimate peptide repertoire diversityFor the small-scale estimation of the unique peptide repertoire diversity of each HLA allotype, peptides were eluted from 200µg of W6/32 purified sHLA material. For label-free relative quantitation of ligands, LC-MS spectra were collected in data-independent (DIA) mode. The3363 msec DIA cycles consisted of one survey MS1 scan followed by 34 MS2 fragment scans with 25 m/z transmission windows overlapping by 1 m/z, covering a mass range of 300-1150 m/z. DIA data was interpreted by Skyline 3.5.0.9319. First, an annotated fragment spectrum library was exported into an mzXML by PEAKS 7.0 from the large-scale de novo identification experiments. For HLA-B*15:01, HLA-B*46:01 and HLA-C*01:02 the library consisted of 8868, 3313 and 1073 peptides, respectively. The library was imported into Skyline for analysis. For each peptide in the library at least 8 ions were monitored including the precursor, precursor+1, precursor+2, and the top 5 most intense fragment ions (transitions). Only peptide matches in any given sample with library dot-product scores of > 0.7 were considered a true hit. For all of the hits, the intensity for each peptide was determined using a summed area underneath the curve for all transition ion extracted ion chromatograms. Intensity data for each peptide were normalized to the combined intensity of four HLA-A*02:01 restricted West-Nile virus derived standard reference peptides (RLDDDGNFQL, ATWAENIQV, YTMDGEYRL, and SLFGQRIEV). These reference peptides were added to the denatured complexes to give a concentration of 400nM for each peptide. Sequence encoding the D1 and D2 domains (amino acids 1-200) of KIR2DL3*001 and a Cterminal BirA ligase site (amino acid sequence: GLNDIFEAQKIEWHE) was cloned into the bacterial expression vector pet30A (EMD Biosciences), immediately downstream of sequence encoding a 6-His purification tag. This construct was transformed into Rosetta 2 BL21 (DE3)

TABREF7.text: The cell pellet was re-suspended in 50ml lysis buffer (10mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, 25% sucrose, 1mM EDTA [Hoefer], 1mM PMSF [Sigma]) in the presence of lysozyme (1mg/ml) [Sigma] to facilitate cell lysis and incubated on ice for 30 mins. Cell lysis was augmented by ultrasonication for 20 mins and cell lysate was collected by centrifugation (30,000 rpm for 25 min). The cell lysate was washed a further 3 times in 60ml chilled lysis buffer, each time discarding the supernatant. Following the final wash the cell pellet was re-suspended and solubilized in 40ml denaturation buffer (8M urea [EMD Millipore], 25mM 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid (MES) [Sigma] pH 6.0, 1mM EDTA [Hoefer], 1mM dithiothreitrol (DTT) [Sigma]). Following dissolution of the pellet, any remaining insoluble material was removed by centrifugation (35,000 rpm for 30min). Re-folding of the solubilized KIR2DL3*001 monomer was performed at 10°C by slow addition of 1L of refolding buffer (10mM Tris pH 8, 100mM NaCl, 400mM L-arginine and 1mM DTT [Sigma], 1mM PMSF [Sigma]) and incubation for 48 hours. Refolding was completed at 4°C in a four-step dialysis, each time against 10L of 10mM Tris pH 8 [Bio-Rad], 100mM NaCl, 20mM imidazole [Sigma]) with the remaining insoluble material removed by centrifugation. The dialyzed solution was added to a 5ml HisTrap nickel agarose column (GE Healthcare) and eluted from the column with 25ml of 10mM Tris pH8, 100mM NaCl, 200mM imidazole solution. The eluted fraction containing the soluble KIR2DL3 was purified using a Superdex 200 10/300 GL gel filtration column (GE Healthcare). Biotinylation was performed according to manufacturers instructions (Avidity).
